questions.text: A patient with rheumatoid arthritis has been on treatment for the past 15 years. During an annual eye check-up, her fundus appeared as shown in the picture given. Which of the following anti-rheumatoid drugs likely led to this side effect?
questions.solution:
The image shows bull’s eye maculopathy.

Hydroxychloroquine use is associated with this side effect.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman with rheumatoid arthritis was on DMARD therapy with a drug that increases extracellular adenosine. Which drug was she likely on?
questions.solution:
Methotrexate is the DMARD that increases extracellular adenosine.

It is a dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR) inhibitor that leads to purine synthesis inhibition and this is cytotoxic to lymphocytes.

It also inhibits amino-imidazole carboxamide ribonucleotide (AICAR) transformylase and thymidylate synthetase. This leads to increased extracellular adenosine which is anti-inflammatory.

The increased extracellular adenosine is hepatotoxic and hence monitoring with LFT is needed every 2-3 months.

Related Pearl: Uses of methotrexate (mnemonic: CANCER)

Mnemonic: CANCER

Crohn’s disease

Abortion

Non-Hodgkin lymphoma, ALL

Choriocarcinoma, Sarcoma

Ectopic pregnancy

Rheumatoid arthritis, Psoriasis, Vasculitis

questions.text: A patient with rheumatoid arthritis on treatment with methotrexate came for a follow-up visit. Her peripheral blood smear shows the following finding. What drug can be administered to alleviate this side effect?
questions.solution:
The peripheral smear findings point to a diagnosis of megaloblastic anemia. Folinic acid is given with methotrexate to decrease its side effects. 

Methotrexate is a dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR) inhibitor and thus can lead to a deficiency of folic acid which may present as megaloblastic anemia.

Folinic acid/leucovorin calcium/citrovorum factor is the 5-formyl derivative of tetrahydrofolic acid. Thus, it decreases the side effects caused due to folate deficiency.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs can be used for the treatment of a patient with rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.solution:
Sulfasalazine can be used in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis, as a conventional DMARD. It is also used in the management of ulcerative colitis and regional enteritis.

Sulfasalazine is metabolized into the following:

  • 5-amino salicylic acid (5-ASA) - it is not absorbed and is used to treat ulcerative colitis.
  • Sulfapyridine - it is absorbed and is used to treat rheumatoid arthritis.

It is used as monotherapy in mild cases and as an add-on drug in moderate to severe cases.

Etanercept acts by TNF alpha inhibition. It is a biological DMARD (disease-modifying anti-rheumatoid drug).

Related Pearl: Important drugs for rheumatoid arthritis

1) NSAIDs - analgesic and anti-inflammatory, used as adjunctive for management of uncontrollable symptoms and in acute flares.

2) Glucocorticoids - used in acute flare for rapid control and as initial therapy before the onset of action of DMARDs. Chronic administration of low doses is needed in patients with inadequate response to DMARDs.

  • Prednisolone - oral

  • Triamcinolone - intraarticular
     

3) DMARDs - disease-modifying anti-rheumatoid drugs:

 

- Conventional DMARDs:

  • Methotrexate (MTX)- is an antifolate drug. The DMARD of choice and the anchor drug for combination therapy. Regular LFT monitoring is required.
  • Hydroxychloroquine- is used as monotherapy for early and mild disease and in combination with other DMARDs for severe cases.
  • Sulfasalazine- is a salicylate. It reduces the radiographic progression of the disease.
  • Leflunomide- is a pyrimidine synthase inhibitor used as an alternative to MTX.

- Biologicals:

  • TNF-α antagonists- used in combination with MTX. Has a risk of serious bacterial infections, opportunistic fungal infection & reactivation of latent TB. The TNF-α inhibitors are adalimumab, golimumab, etanercept, infliximab, and certolizumab.
  • Abatacept- a T-cell costimulation inhibitor, used in combination with MTX, leflunomide, etc.
  • Rituximab- an anti-CD20 antibody. Used in refractory disease in combination with MTX.
  • Anakinra- an IL-1 receptor antagonist. It should not be combined with anti-TNF alpha.
  • IL-6 receptor antagonists- tocilizumab and sarilumab are used as monotherapy or combination therapy in moderate to severe disease.  

- Small molecules: 

  • Janus kinase inhibitors: Tofacitinib, baricitinib, and upadacitinib are used as monotherapy or combination therapy.

questions.text: You are using TNF alpha inhibitors in the treatment of a patient with rheumatoid arthritis. Which of the following is not true regarding these drugs?

choices.text: They can also be used in the treatment of plaque psoriasis
They can be used in the treatment of psoriatic arthritis
They can be used in the treatment of lymphomas
They can be used in the treatment of ulcerative colitis

questions.solution:
TNF-α inhibitors are not used in the treatment of lymphomas.

Despite their benefits, multiple potential adverse effects following the use of TNF-alpha inhibitors have been reported. These include:

  • Malignancy (lymphoma)
  • Injection site reactions
  • Infusion reactions
  • Opportunistic infections.

TNF-α inhibitors can be used in the treatment of:

  1. Rheumatoid arthritis
  2. Ankylosing spondylitis
  3. Crohn's disease
  4. Ulcerative colitis
  5. Plaque psoriasis
  6. Psoriatic arthritis.

questions.text: A middle-aged man with rheumatoid arthritis on treatment with methotrexate presents to your OPD complaining of no improvement in his condition. Which of the following is an IL-1 receptor antagonist that can you prescribe for him?
questions.solution:
The IL-1 receptor antagonist that is used in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis is anakinra.

Anakinra is a biological DMARD (Disease Modifying Anti-Rheumatoid Drug) used in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis. All biological DMARDs downregulate the immune system and can lead to adverse effects like opportunistic infections and flaring of latent TB.

questions.text: Which is the monoclonal antibody approved for the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.solution:
The monoclonal antibody approved for the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis is sarilumab.

It is an IL-6 receptor antagonist indicated for the treatment of adults with moderate to severe rheumatoid arthritis who show inadequate response or intolerance to one or more disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs).

Option A: Durvalumab is an anti PD-L1 antibody approved for metastatic urothelial cancer.

Option C: Nivolumab is a fully human monoclonal IgG4 antibody that blocks the interaction between PD-1 (Programmed cell Death-1) receptor and its ligands.

Option D: Pembrolizumab (formerly called lambrolizumab or MK-3475) is a humanized monoclonal IgG4-κ isotype antibody that blocks the interaction between PD-1 and its ligands. Nivolumab and pembrolizumab are used to treat advanced melanoma.

questions.text: Which of the following is a Janus kinase inhibitor approved for use in rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.solution:
Baricitinib was approved for use in patients with rheumatoid arthritis. It is a Janus kinase inhibitor.

Oral Janus kinase inhibitors for rheumatoid arthritis and upadacitinib and tofacitinib.

Option A: Ruxolitinib is a Janus kinase inhibitor, approved for use in various forms of myelofibrosis, polycythemia vera, and acute graft vs host disease.

Option C: Denosumab is a RANK-L inhibitor that is approved for the treatment of osteoporosis.

Option D: Dasatinib and ponatinib are BCR-ABL tyrosine kinase inhibitors indicated for the treatment of CML.

questions.text: Which among the following is not an indication for the use of corticosteroids in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis?

choices.text: Management of acute disease flares while on therapy with DMARDs
As bridging therapy initially, till DMARDs take effect
Chronic therapy in cases that cannot be controlled with DMARDs
As monotherapy for the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis

questions.solution:
Glucocorticoids are not used as monotherapy for the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis (RA).

High doses of glucocorticoids may be needed to treat severe extraarticular manifestations of RA.

Intraarticular injection of triamcinolone can be considered for one/few actively inflamed joints.

Option A: A burst of glucocorticoids for 1-2 weeks may be prescribed to manage acute disease flares. 

Option B: They may be administered as bridging therapy initially to achieve rapid disease control till DMARDs take effect, which may take several weeks or even months. 

Option C: Chronic therapy with low doses may be needed to control the disease in patients with an inadequate response to DMARD therapy.
